HTML ref-card

  • HTML Document
    • index.htm / index.html 
      <!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
<title>Page Title</title>
</head>
<body>
<h1>Heading 1</h1>
<p>Paragraph</p>
</body>
</html>
  • HTML is Not Case Sensitive
    • The HTML standard does not require lowercase tags, but W3C recommends lowercase in HTML, and demands lowercase for stricter document types like XHTML.
  • HTML Element
    • HTML element: <tagname attribute="property:value;">text</tagname>
    • empty element <br /> or <br> (without a closing tag)
    • nested elements <div><span></span></div>
  • HTML attributes
    • HTML attributes provide additional information about HTML elements.
    • The HTML standard does not require quotes around attribute values. However, W3C recommends quotes in HTML, and demands quotes for stricter document types like XHTML.
    • quotes around attribute values
      • <p title='one "two" tree'> double quotes are most common
      • <p title="one 'two' tree"> single quotes can also be used
  • Browser: View HTML Source / Inspect an HTML Element
    • Right-click in an HTML page and select "View Page Source" (in Chrome) or "View Source" (in Edge)
    • Right-click on an element (or a blank area), and choose "Inspect" or "Inspect Element" to see what elements are made up of (you will see both the HTML and the CSS). You can also edit the HTML or CSS on-the-fly in the Elements or Styles panel that opens.
  • URLs
    • HTML Tutorial https://www.w3schools.com/html/
    • HTML: HyperText Markup Language | MDN https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML
    • WHATWG HTML5 Living Standard http://whatwg.org/html/
    • W3C Recommendation: HTML5 http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/
    • W3C Recommendation: HTML5.1 2nd Edition http://www.w3.org/TR/html51/
    • W3C Recommendation: HTML5.2 http://www.w3.org/TR/html52/

code render name / description
<!DOCTYPE html> HTML5 <!DOCTYPE> declaration
The <!DOCTYPE> declaration is not case sensitive.
<html lang="en">
<html lang="en-US">		 HTML root element
  • <html> element is the root element
  • Always include the lang attribute inside the <html> tag, to declare the language of the Web page. This is meant to assist search engines and browsers.
    • HTML Language Code Reference https://www.w3schools.com/tags/ref_language_codes.asp
<h1>Header 1<h1>
<h6>Header 6<h6>		 Heading element,
<h1> to <h6>
Important! Use only one <h1> per page - this should represent the main heading/subject for the whole page. Also, do not skip heading levels - start with <h1>, then use <h2>, and so on.
<p>paragraph</p>

paragraph

 paragraph element
<br />
line break
<hr />

<img src="/img/smile.png" alt="smile face" /> image
  • link to source
    • Absolute URL <img src="https://www.dzyubak.com/img/img1.jpg" alt="..." />
    • Relative URL, relative to the current page (begins w/o slash) <img src="img1.jpg" alt="..." />
    • Relative URL, relative to the current domain (begins w/ slash) <img src="/media/img/img1.jpg" alt="..." /> (recommended, except for Google SEO, for example, not in rel="canonical")
  • The required alt attribute specifies an alternate text for an image
  • The <img> tag should also contain width and height
    • <img src="img1.jpg" alt="alternate text" width="100" height="200" />
    • BUT better specify width and height in CSS class
